This is my favorite breakfast in town.  Portions are solid, price is a little high for the food, but the view breaks your heart and the place is real, devoid of the meta-smugness that permeates the Bay Area.  If they were open after 6:30 I'd have a drinking problem.  Oh, wait . . .
author: John H.

description:
I found this place when I went for a lunch meeting with this dude Jr (gaffling ass), but I kept it in mind as the years went by to become my getaway from the inner city hustle and bustle with its cramped eateries. Sitting at the edge of a hillside, you will be blessed with a calming view if you're the lucky one that grabs a window booth, which overlooks the former place of The Sutro Baths, and also is a hop skip and jump from the recently remodeled historic Cliffhouse. Located between Ocean Beach and back way to the Presidio area, this is a great addition to an evening after scarfing down some grub, because you may want to follow the roadway down for a calorie burning stroll either on the beach to watch the sun set or walk along the aging stone walk following the GREAT HIGHWAYs rolling path. For you lovebirds? This is definitely a romantic after thought too.
SHINOBI 009
author: SHINOBI Z.

description:
This place has the most amazing view of any diner in the world.  There are restaurants with better views, but diners?

The food here isn't so great, and the service can be slow, but you probably came here for the view anyway, so who cares?  Well, I realize a lot of people care.  I'm not trying to disparage their opinions, but this place is worth visiting if only for the novelty of it.
author: John S.

description:
A cozy little shack that just might have a slightly better view than the Cliff House--but expect a wait if you want that window seat.  Louis' is family-owned and (I think) operated, and the service makes you feel right at home.

An absolutely perfect cure for the morning-after hangover.  Try their French toast with a cup of strong coffee; it's the best way to start the day.  However, they only accept cash (and travelers' checks with proper I.D.) so make sure you still have a few dollars left from the drunken cab ride home the night before.
author: Andrea U.

description: I really want to give this place 4 stars. The customer service here is great, but soooo slow!  The food was great. We ordered the chili & cheese burger with 2 patties (omg, sooo filling but soo good!), also ordered minestrone soup, tuna melt sandwich which was delicious. This place is not cheap at all, good food, good customer service (the lady that served us was super nice), but they were way too slow in taking orders. We sat about 20 min before she came to take our orders.
author: Alyce l.

description: The view at Louis' is incredibe.  The Sutro Baths plus the inevitable fog make quite the impression on the eye.  If only the food at Louis' made the same impression.  It's mostly traditional diner fare, but with prices jacked up so as to charge you for the view.  I'd be ok with this if the food held up a little more.  I decided to skip the breakfast for dinner idea and went with an open faced roast beef sandwich with potatoes.  The dish would have been more successful if they had never called it a sandwich.  A sad slice of Wonderbread sat under the mountain of decent roast beef, but due to the expansive lake of au jus that coated the whole plate, the bread became soggy.  Au Jus soaked bread sounds good, but when it's on the verge of being limp while dry, the wet version just tastes like a bad sponge.  The mashed potatoes were also of the decent variety, but more thick than creamy.  My date's burger looked small and sad.  As he ate it (and he did like it), I counted at least fifteen places he could have gotten a better burger for the same price.  So my evaluation is that this is a place to come with the folks for a milkshake (the one thing they seemed to do right), but save the appetite for Chinese food.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
4 stars for the memories, but the reality is 3 stars for the food.

I'm not a fan of processed cheese in my omeletes, but it's what I get at Louis. I'm really there for the view and the company of my friends.

Portions are pretty big -- I couldn't finish my omelet, hash browns and english muffin.

Service is pretty fast and it can be full of tourists, but when the tourists are gone, nothing but the locals who sit at the tables talking about the old Outer Richmond with Funland remain -- and those are the best ones to talk to.
author: Carina M.

description:
The wait = lengthy.
The view = pretty.
The cheeseburger = tiny.

And the pickles that came with my burger were even tinier - they looked like two green, crinkle-cut nickels.

Due to its location, Louis' provides a touristy feel-good experience - I would come here again for brunch if I wanted to show off the area (Ocean Beach/Sutro Baths/Lands End) to friends visiting from out of town. However, it didn't quite satisfy my "dragged my tired ass out of bed early on a random Sunday morning for some super tasty food" expectations.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
So maybe its just me, maybe I am weird, but when you are the "beach" don't you get a hankering to drink a beer or some form of alcoholic beverage for that matter. So last weekend, I walk in with my gf and her parents (they are visiting from the East Coast). We notice no beers on the tables, oh wait, there is something, ALL Miller Genuine Draft. So I kindly ask the waitress, "we'd like seating for 4 people and do you sell wine/beer?"

She gives me a look like I just wrote the word Satan with a big black smelly marker all over her white toy poodle and says "There is a full bar at the Cliff House" So I ask, "so you don't sell beer or wine?" Then she responds, "yes, but there is a full bar at the Cliff House down the hill" and then glares at us, willing us to go away.

I look at my gf, she looks at her Mom, we look at each other and then decided to walk out. My spider sense tells me that it would not be a pleasant place to have a bite and a glass of wine/beer.

So I hereby give this place 0 stars. Why?
Because it is taking up valuable real estate which a cool fun place could be using. 

Is it too much to ask, to drink a beer/wine at a place at the beach, and yes, that isnt too stuff like the CliffHouse?

So we ended up at the Cliff House, blah.
author: Fabian O.

description:
I really like this place.  The view is great, but it's just a little diner (which is why I love it).  The prices have gone up a bit, but they are actually using more organic foods, local produce and (more) humanely raised meats.  Obviously, the prices are going to go up if the quality of the ingredients go up.

The food will not change your life, it's a step up from Denny's so it's not high end dining.  I go here because I like how old school it is.  I like the throwback waitstaff, I like the view and I like that I can get eggs and toast and potatoes without  french feta and arugula and tapinade and and roasted beets and whatever else breakfast places try to throw in your food in SF.  Sometimes I want a pretentious breakfast and sometimes I want scrambled eggs in a diner.  

I have only gone for a weekday breakfast because I don't want to wait for a table in a diner and I am less into diner food for dinner.  But it hits the spot on occasion.  It's a 3 star place that I am giving 4 stars due to view and history.
author: Bianca G.

description:
2 stars for food. 5 stars for the view. 3 1/2 stars for service.

Regular coffee shop fare... this time I got the grilled cheese (on whole wheat with tomato, fries on the side) and coffee. I liked it, although I think I'll see if I can substitute fruit for the fries next time. 

If you're looking for a little more "class" and variety, check out the Cliff House or the Beach Chalet (further down the beach by the windmill). Both of those restaurants are pricier, but have better food and full bars.
author: Suzi G.

description:
Old San Francisco at its best!  I was delighted to discover it still exists!  

On a rare and glorious sunny day at the beach, this place hit the spot as we indulged in ample breakfast scrambles (my husband loved their generosity with the cheese) and killer views that have not been co-opted by some hipster place with high prices for food artfully arranged on a plate.  No, this is old school:   bottomless cups of coffee,  family members seating, serving, and ringing you up as  the patriarch sits at the counter greeting customers.  The breakfast is a little more expensive than other places (around the price of a hipster bar's martini) but well worth it for the food, the warmth of the greeting and service, and the view that goes on forever.  If you miss the San Francisco of yore, this is the place to visit.
author: L. S.

description: Food is pretty good, though not exceptional and a tad pricey.  The real reason to come here is for the ocean views and the amazing location.  It's a treat to drive out to Louie's and a great place to take out-of-towners.  There can often be a wait, however.   This restaurant has been around for more than 6 or 7 decades I think, and is right next to the Sutro Baths ruins...so quite an interesting place.  Definitely a fave for my brunch list.
author: Vivek A.

description: Much better experience the second time around. Food quality is still average, but we had a much better waiter this time and the average food seemed better prepared. It's a nice place to go on occasion.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
We went there for breakfast and it was decent, what you would expect from a diner.  

Way overpriced but you are paying for the awesome view. My wife and I spent $35 before the tip.  
2 pancakes
Sausage
2 eggs
Omelet, ham & cheese. -- Would have gotten more but it was$1.25 per topping, $1,.25 for Onions!
roast potatoes
2 OJs
1 Milk
= $35

They probably have to pay a lot for that location and the views were worth it.
author: Rob L.

description:
Dear Louis,
I'm missing you terribly, yeah, your breakfast is not so cheap anymore and nothing special, but you get alot for the money and I do love diner food. There isn't any other that has a view like you do, anywhere! Ocean and fog, sea lions and cormorants, oh my! Ocean air always makes food taste that much better. Hope to see you soon! xxoo P
author: the L.

description:
A great little diner!  I used to come here for breakfast often when I lived in the city - I loved having their hamburger patty and eggs with fries for breakfast (yeah, fries over hash browns any day for me).  Now living elsewhere, it's been quite a while since I've been here.  
Recently I re-visited this place during a trip up.  It's still just as good as I remembered it to be and as always, a delicious, satisfying breakfast.  It also just never gets tiring to be able to stare out at the ocean and what remains of Sutro Baths while you're dining there.
author: Crys L.

description:
I heart greasy spoon joints. I double red heart greasy spoon joints with retro 60s decor and lovely views of the great Pacific. 

My ham and two eggs breakfast (which I ate at approximately 5:30 pm on a Saturday night) hit the spot. It could have had something to do with the hash browns that were drenched in butter...yes, that must have been it. I also don't have English muffins very often these days, so that was an additional bonus. 

This would be the best place for a hangover, except you'd definitely have to keep your sunglasses on since the windows are big and the sunshine is plentiful (unless that SF fog starts to roll in...!).
author: lindsay w.

description: The food is nothing to write home about here, standard diner fare. Just a cut above Denny's. But of course, you come here for the view. It's almost worth it.
author: Matt J.

description:
Had a friend in from E-town, and she wanted to have a drink with an ocean view. We tried to go to the Cliff House but I couldn't stomach all the tourists (and, am I just spatially challenged or are all the bars there hiding somewhere? It was like pulling teeth trying to find an actual bar) so we bellied up to the counter at Louis' for a cold Anchor Steam.

The $5/bottle wasn't worth the view, and the service was unnecessarily grumpy. Next time I'll try harder at Cliff House.
author: Priya S.

description:
$30.00 for two plates with fried eggs, obviously frozen potato cubes and a paltry , overcooked veggie omelet?  My friend and I went there for brunch on a week day recently, had to wait for a booth seat and were served with less than enthusiastic attitudes.  I observed the "tourists" there being overcharged for steak and eggs, etc. Louis' recently renovated (guess they changed up the Formica flooring).  Anyhow, unless you want to pay far too much for sub-par food and a view that you can get from The Cliff house and pay only a few bucks more, don't waste your time.  Also, they don't take Credit/Debit cards but have a usurer's ATM machine there.

Long time SF resident tired of being overcharged for crap....
author: Annie F.

description:
If you're looking for a great view while eating breakfast, go here! Overlooking the ocean while slapping those pancakes on my  face makes me euphoric! LOL!

The food is good and the atmoshere is fun and touristic...notice that I gave this place 4 stars because of its view. This place is always packed as usual...that's a good sign! =)
author: Marc E.

description:
It's just a diner, but it's got that great view and the food ... it's not bad!
The servers are really friendly, but don't go there if you want a mimosa, they don't serve them.
Grab a quick bite and spend the rest of the day on the beach, even if it's not a sunny day, ocean beach is always rad.
author: Colleen B.

description: Stellar view.  Great location.  Average, but over-priced food could have been more palatable if our server hadn't been such a dud.  She did nothing terrible, but it was clear she wasn't into serving our table.  We were four women celebrating one of our birthdays.  Maybe it was the silly hats we were wearing, maybe she thought a party of women wouldn't tip, maybe she was just having a bad day.  Whatever, she had the power to make our experience a great one and she chose not to do that.  My advice to her -- quit this day job and get soemthing that suits your bland personality.
author: Charna G.

description:
I ate here on Monday morning and four hours later was completely debilitated with horrible food poisoning! I cannot recommend any restaurant (or diner) that will poison their customers and therefore, Louis', you will receive a bad review from me.  24 hours later, I can finally digest  soup and bread... alas, my mediocre breakfast wasn't worth it.

Eaters beware of the dirty kitchen inside Louis'!!!
author: Douglas M.

description:
Louis, I offer you a new slogan: Great view; Old school Medicore Menu.  

Theres a little disclaimer at the bottom that its a concessionary of GGNRA, which kinda points the reason that the only vegetables on the menu are sides of tomato or onions for the omelets.  

That being said, the pancakes were almost as amazing as the view;  thick, well made, not too brown or too mushy.  Pretty much just goodness from a mix.  

I can't imagine going out of my way to go there, though;  if I want to pay a lot of money for breakfast with a view I'll go out of my way to go to Greens.
author: Nora B.

description:
The food is alright and you get a lot of it, but the prices are a bit high for coffee-shop food.  Really, you're paying for the view (which is awesome, I admit), because you can't throw a rock in this city without hitting a coffee-shop that serves better food than Louis' for cheaper.

But the service is good, and if you have guests this is a great place to take them.  Parking is easy and the wait time varies but usually isn't horrendously long.  The cheese omelet topped with chili is totally decent (price? $10.95, yikes!), so whatever.

After you eat you can walk off breakfast with a stroll down to the Sutro Baths, or up the Lands End trail.  Nice.
author: Mark G.

description:
This place is pretty small so it is better to either come really early or allow yourself time to wait for a table. Not all the tables there have a great view so make sure you ask ahead. 

The food was typical diner, greasy, and home cookin'  but sometimes that is exactly what you are craving. Sometimes when I am done eating here I walk down the path to where the old Sutra Baths use to be and climb around on the rocks or poke around in the tunnels, it is always the start to a great day!
author: Amanda M.

description:
at the time of writing this there are 99 reviews for louis' restaurant, i'm 100!

this place is just your regular ol' diner, with a magnificent view. i hear the fish and chips are good, which i may be back for (since i'm a sucker for a good fish and  chips meal).
author: Ameer N.

description:
Good place for a "normal", predictable breakfast.
Cash only.  Great views...
author: Bette S.

description:
How is this so highly rated?  

My one visit will be my last.  We waited an incredibly long time.  "Great, a sure sign of a good restaurant" I was thinking.  Oh, how I was wrong.  The food was pricey, and awful.  I am pretty sure the chili on my eggs was out of a can.  Everyone's dish was bland and lukewarm.  

Now, a restaurant's poor food fare can frequently be forgiven if the staff is charming or friendly.  Louis' couldn't even pull that off.  The service was inattentive and rude.  I had the gall to ask for a refill of water, after which our waiter took the prudent approach of ignoring us altogether.  Though I shouldn't complain too much...another staffer took time out of his busy schedule of staring off in to space to sleazily hit on the women at our table!

If you want the views, you can go to the Sutro baths without paying for overpriced garbage at the hands of a creepy staff...
author: Casey H.

description: The food is really good but the view is AMAZING! Why go to the cliff house when you can have awesome breakfast food at a cheap price. The service is ok and they only take cash but other than that, I have never had bad breakfast food there and am always staring out the window at the view :)
author: Chris D.

description:
We were sandy and windblown after a day at Crissy Field followed by a hike at Land's End--beautiful Spring weather by the way. Our first time and we don't really know what they offer--perhaps a light snack of  clam chowder? They only have the red, which is not my fav, so we decide to make it early dinner. Hub has the hamburger (medium rare) and I have the fish and chips. For diner fare, pretty good. I have a glass of wine. A super-generous pour in a little decanter. Okay stuff for $4.75. My husband has an Anchor Steam. We walk out for under $40. Now when did that last happen?
Afterward we checked out what we missed at the Cliff House: crowds (lots of them) and much higher prices.
author: M F.

description:
What a great view! Service was great as well. The waitresses were on it,my coffee was always full. Unfortunately thats where it ends...

This places offers nothing more than the view.The food was brutal,bland at best and WAY over priced. $10 for rubber eggs,hashbrowns that were barely cooked and two tiny pieces of sausage. But does it really matter? They have the view to fill the seats. As I sat in my booth with the lady picking at my crappy breakfast all I good hear was "ohhh it's so beautiful, look at the view Bill, look at the seagulls" Unfortunately never once did someone say "wow this food is great." "It was really worth the $5 for those extra 2 strips of bacon"
Why invest in a solid menu if you got the view to pull them in right? Good business model, crappy food. A great place to go if your from Illinois and don't know any better. I'll never go back. This is basically a tourist trap.
author: Kevin K.

description: What is wrong with you people working there... Me and my friends are paying customers and how dare you rudely told us to move to another table just because another party came...waited for 30 long minutes to get a table waited another 15 minutes to order our food and the dumb lady kept telling us she will be right with us... C'mon this is San Francisco and are suppose to strive for great service... I gave this restaurant the benefit of a doubt but this place just messed everything up for me and my friends... Lady with the white nail polish you suck so badly that I don't even understand why you are there to work... Your customer service skills are so HORRIBLE... Yes I give it that the restaurant was busy but that doesn't give you a right to be an asshole... Like seriously who trained you there... Coming from a food industry background telling any customers to move tables is beyond unacceptable... I wish I can give no stars... Please do not come here you are better off at beach chalet or at cliff house... I really do not want anyone else to go through what we went through... I would even go to Mel's to get better service and better food... I understand about the view but trust me you would rather buy food from another place and sit on top of lands end and enjoy better views... This place traumatized me...
author: Amy C.

description: Ok, so realistically this place should probably get 1 star for the price to food quality...but I knew what I was getting into and got exactly what I expected.  The food has truly not changed in 50 years.  The sausage and cheese omelette was exactly as I make it at home...chopped up sausage links and american cheese.  It's pretty decent, but for $10+ it is a bit pricey.  The waffle is like the one's my mom used to make at home, not a belgian waffle.  The view is great, while I could barely close the bathroom door after me.  Overall, the food is decent, but overpriced, and I wouldn't recommend going there unless you are up for nostalgia with a view.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a wee lad, so there's a lot of nostalgia in my positive review, but I think the place lives up to the memories you can make. The view is amazing, the atmosphere is the right kind of quaint, and for my tastes the food is great. 

Much better than the rubbish they call food down at the main Cliffhouse restaurant a few yards down the walk. Good soup, good grilled cheese, good fries, good prices. 

They stopped serving manhatten clam chowder there, which almost tempts me into giving it four stars, but if you didn't experience the chowder when they had it then I can't say you'll feel you're having a lesser experience. Just go.
author: Abe D.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped in here on a really foggy day on our way to the Sutro Baths. We just wandered in to warm up but decided to stay for the atmosphere and some chili. 

I'd most definitely go back because it really set a mood for us - Louis' reminded me of an East Coast diner and I almost felt like I was on the Maine coast. It wasn't crowded at all, but that may have been due to the weather as it wasn't a great beach day, unless you like the fog. 

I'd recommend this little diner because it has a retro, sort of isolated, and cozy feel and good, polite service, and it's not like every other diner. A special place!
author: Heidi G.

description: The sad experience that I had here, left much to be desired. It has a lovely view, best you can get, if you can get a window seat. I suggest groups larger than 2 as well because they are given priority for tables. If you are 1 or 2, the counter is your place, which has a lovely view of the wait staff. We were seated relatively quickly, after being bumped twice by families (my boyfriend and I) for a table with a view. We then sat down, got our well topped off coffees, and looked over the menu. General good diner fare there. I ordered the Louis' Benedict, and my sig. other got a cheeseburger as it was closer to noon. We received our food shortly after, about 15 or so, and as it would turn out, the eggs were hard boiled through, and the potatoes were deep fried squares from a bag. Nothing more, nothing less. My boyfriend still enjoyed his burger, but it left me feeling it was lackluster. As he put it, he liked it because it reminded him of what you would make at a beach cookout. Bun, meat, american cheese, lettuce, pickle and tomato on a plain sponge bun. The fries are crinkle cut like they were bought at Smart and Final. I like the premise of this place, but it needs to come back to the future. We have fresh ingredients readily available to us, and San Francisco, is a culinary centre. Let's pick it up Louis'...and get a chef who can at least poach eggs without them turning to hard boiled. The wait staff was very nice, and I think the hostess was new, so good luck to her in my dearest sincerity, she did great considering the chaos. Getting back to the point, they need to improve their food. I walked out $35 shorter than coming in, and that was for a sad cheeseburger, badly cooked eggs, and weak coffee for 2.50 a piece...better step it up Louis'. I understand that you're still going since 1931 or something, but you really only have your location to go off of.
author: Brianna S.

description: This is a classic case of a restaurant not having to draw customers for their food because they have an ideal location.  Its got stunning views of the area and tons of tourists and hikers pass through the area with few eating options. You would NOT want to come here because of the food. Its WAY OVER PRICED basic diner grub, not any better than Denny's.  That being said, I live nearby and love eating here for lunch once in a while due to the view and atmosphere. Its laid back and comfortable with a killer view of the park and ocean. The staff has always been nice and it has a relaxing, no nonsense feel to the place. I like to come here by myself with a book and relax for about hour as I munch on a sandwich or soup looking out at the ocean.
author: Nathan S.

description:
Ooh Delicious.  Nice menu for a hung-over morning.  We went here the morning after Christmas and I learned all about the tiger attack at the zoo via text message from the corner booth.  It's kind of a minus that they don't take reservations, and the parking sucks, but you can pretty much see if the wait is going to be terrible when you drive past.  The wait for a two-top won't be too bad, but I would never try to take a group larger than four here.

  The view makes up for any of that.  I mean, I have an ocean view from my couch here, but that hanging-over-the-edge vantage never fails to impress me.  In fact I usually can't remember the name of this place and call it Cliff's.  My fiance knows what the hell I'm talking about.

They make some serious burgers, but I usually come for breakfast and order items a la carte.  Prices are good and service is always excellent, as it should be in a smallish dining room like Louis'.  And for a hangover breakfast, the coffee is perfect.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
Birthday DAY took a trip out to the city for some extreme biking (unplanned) and a nice lunch of my choice. You know, played the tourist thing and all... 

Well, I chose Louis'!! After driving by this place a gazillion times on the weekends and being discouraged by the 10-deep line out the door I knew this would be our lunch destination....how crowded could it be on a Tuesday afternoon? 

It was not bad at all! Wait was 5 minutes tops, and we got a great corner spot right next to the window (awesome!!). Being that it was my birthday and all I did not hesitate to go all out at this b****! I ordered the open face Roast Beef sandwich (complete with Mashed Potatoes and Gravy) with a side of horseradish....I also ordered a pre-lunch 'dinner' salad. Both were awesome!! Could not even come close to finishing the Roast Beef because it covered my ENTIRE plate....holy crap that thing was loaded!! Plus I had to save room for desert!! 

I had a slice of some wonderful Cherry Pie, a-la-mode, of course! Coffee too....wow....what a wonderful meal....and it's a friggin' diner!! 

I can't wait to go back on a random day off in the middle of the week.....I wouldn't dare to try it on a weekend.....leave it for the real tourists....
author: Tia A.

description:
Pro's: Great view & friendly service
Con's: The food is less than mediocre. If you stick to fried eggs & sausage with toast its OK. But stay clear of the omelete. The hash browns taste like cardboard. At the prices they charge the food should be much better. Its a typical tourist rip-off. You pay for the nice view and they must not care about the food quality.
author: stephen b.

description: We were seated rather quickly but the wait is longer if you want a window seat. Our coffee and water were always filled and the food was absolutely delicious. The english muffin tasted homemade! Great experience and the prices were very reasonable as well!
author: ERIKA W.

description:
Be careful of a guy named thomas working there, he's one of the waiters...he has one of the weirdest sense of humors out there....

I was eating and he was telling me some dead baby jokes....i mean, wtf?

The view is nothing special...if i want to see water i'd look in a bottle. 
Be careful when going, since they only take cash, criminals usually hang around outside....

The food is pretty good, they use real eggs!

I go every once in a while...so yeah i'm qualified to write this review.
author: Steven C.

description:
Perhaps you've heard of the Ken Burn's Effect or the Streisand Effect. One is related to film techniques the other is related to how the Internet works differently than the real world.

I'd like to introduce The Yelp Effect (3/2/2008), if it hasn't been chronicled before.  The Yelp Effect reflects a cycle the good word-of-mouth on the Yelp website has on a business.  Sending business to a store, restaurant or service. This exposure adds stress to the business and makes the undiscovered charm of the place battered by too many people trying to access it. 

It happened to my old favorite Thai place. It was the bomb. Now after a huge amount of good reviews what they did so well has become hard to excuse.  For years they had the Zagat sticker in the window, just like they probably take Diner's Club credit cards for the 12 businessmen in town who still carry that card.  The food was yummy and we returned again and again. With the arrival of Yelp you could see the fuss gathering in the line-to-be-seated.  Now, alas we don't go there as much. The quality has gone down under the pressure of the quantity they must produce. The charm of the undiscovered becomes a tired mistress who needs a few nights off. Some places are built for the on coming crush of interest but the ones that are not ready seem to wilt.  

This is the Yelp Effect.

So, I mention this as a warning. Yes, Louis' Restaurant is a fabulous breakfast spot. The food is certainly above average, the servers are very kind and the prices are very reasonable. The location: rain or shine - clear or foggy, will be worth the journey. It doesn't seem like you could hurt this place by driving a little more business their way. Still, I do so with respect to the Yelp Effect.
author: BirminghamBill S.

description:
The modern California breakfast seems to require an exotic mixture of applewood, game birds, Eggbeaters, and passionflower infusions.  These breakfasts are normally delicious, but fail to satisfy when one is craving an old-school greasy spoon experience.

Louis does a great job with the meat-and-potatoes diner experience.  Because it's a diner.  I've always been happy with the food I've eaten there, particularly if I can time my appearance in between waves of tourists.

Diner food would normally only merit three stars (at best) from me, but the view from this place merits a star of its own.  I make a point of going here and exploring the Sutro Bath ruins every time I make it back to the city.
author: Jim C.

description:
After months of photographing in the area and seeing this place packed, I decided to try it today...  and will not be returning anytime soon!! Ten-minute wait with NO host at the entrance and no sign. I actually had to ask after a few minutes waiting for nobody. I was walking in and about outside while ducking inside to see if they had called my name and when it was time, a girl just said: "I have a booth for you in the back" and simply pointed "over there". Sure enough, I went there and there was an empty booth for me. After another 10mins when no waitress showed up to ask me if I were dead or listlessly bored but patient, I got up and snagged a waitress. She waited on me right there and then!! I ordered a hamburger as I hadn't eaten all day after snapping pixs at a nearby russian church, and a bowl of the red clam chowder. The burger came with one half leaf of lettuce, one tomato and two pickles and was still lousy. The fries were a standard out of your frozen bag of dead potatoes. The hamburger was so tasteless that I thought of putting ketchup on it, and did use it for the thick but tasteless fries. I make better fries and burgers than this!!!  The clam chowder was okay with something, and pieces of potatoes and celery in it, but was much tastier than that burger & fries. Ordered a root beer float and it was standard also....   

One thing that bothered me was the sight of one of the very young waitresses pouring ketchup from an almost empty bottle into another. Haven't they any sense to do that behind a partition or in the kitchen? She was slapping the bottle butt trying to get the ketchup to move, which of course attracted a lot of stares. These people don't have a lot of common sense, but do have a lot of common tasteless food.

I ain't returning and I ain't recommending this place. I feel sorry for all the tourists who have paid (a lot) to eat here. Sure, the view is wonderful but....  at the motel across the street at the intersection, there's a tiny restaurant whose burgers are MUCH better than these!! YUCKy!!
author: Tony L.

description:
Okay.  When you are hanging around the Sutro Bath Ruins and you want to have not only a spectacular view, but eat at a place that is not going to make you feel like you have to put a second mortgage on your home to pay for it?

Louis is the place to go.  The wait can be wicked monster long and getting the prime tables by the ocean overlooking that jutty rock is like winning the lottery, the waitstaff is lovely.  Please, talk to the African American Busman.  He remembers everyone and every time I go in there is a wonderful chatty fellow who has about 97 thousand "Ladies".  We went in there for Valentines Day last year and he remembered me from every single time I was in there.  Including the first time six years ago.

The food is simple.  Chili with cheese and onions, hamburgers.  fish and fries.  That glass case full of cakes and pies.  Wine in a glass that is not a wine glass.  :) 

But who cares if they bring you wine in a water glass??  The food is good, the view is beautiful, you can afford it and the staff is friendly.

It is mom and pop good eats.  In the luckiest location in San Francisco.  :)
author: Shaun L.

description: laid back, gorgeous views, nice family atmosphere. its a solid basic diner, which is just what we wanted. pie was great, and they serve local beers too. simple and satisfying, and the location is so cool.
author: A R.

description: Haven't been here in ages, but used to a lot with my girlfriends just for a simple and reasonable lunch with an incredible view. Most people know the Cliff House restaurant, but prices are 3x higher there. Louis' is probably the last known cheap eat along that beach front. Food is your typical diner style burgers, omelettes, sandwiches. Decor sucks -- looks like they've done nothing to it in about 50 years. It was opened in the late 30s so go figure! Service is not bad, but mad rush starts around lunch time, so go for an early lunch and perhaps have access to a window table to fully enjoy the gorgeous view (on a clear day that is).
author: Anita L.

description: The service is bad, the food is meh and the prices are outrageous.  I used to love this place but I can't even think about going back.  They've lost that homey touch that made it popular.  The view is still great which is why it gets 2 stars rather than 1.
author: Karen C.

description:
The view is five star on most days, in and of itself, worth the trip. The food however, is generally awful. How can a restaurant screw up breakfast? Well, how about fake syrup! If you make mediocre pancakes and use real maple syrup, you might get another star but, mediocre pancakes and cheap fake syrup's gets you one star! The coffee is the worst in SF. This is in a city that prides itself on a good cup of coffee. And how about serving it HOT for god-sake! Greasy hashbrowns...well the list is endless. 

I live in this neighborhood and wrote a letter to the owner/manager, a NICE letter, suggesting a few upgrades, like improving the coffee. Waited a few months and absolutely nothing has changed. Part of the problem is the long term lease (20 years I think) and catering to tourist, who come for the natural beauty of Lands End. The owners are in this for the almighty buck, showing little interest in providing a quality dining experience.  They use cheap processed products for maximum profit. 

I won't go back!
author: Steve H.

description: If you like to spend your money on a mediocre diner, than this is the place for you! Me being a party of five with an infant, walks into the diner and immediately could already tell what type of place this was. The manager himself (Tommy); instead of greeting his new customers chatting it up with a co-worker about some movie he had seen (Sin city) had asked us to "hold on for a second" until after he finished his conversation with said co-worker. After we were seated and ordered our meals, a movie was played on my cellular device for the infant so he would be relaxed, comfortable and quiet while waiting for his food the manager makes his way over to the table to ask us to turn the volume off of the phone because he was annoyed and it was noisy (mind you the volume of the IPhone wasn't all the way up) That was strike number two, and if I'm paying money for this place I would rather not stick around for strike three. After our drinks came I had my family all packed up to leave. Our waitress brought over to-go cups for our drinks that we had paid for before we left. Now enough about the scene; the place itself isn't anything good to look at. The place is a dump! Dirty, customers cramped on the same tables with other customers, and the managers terrible manners. The only reason I gave this place one star  was because there is no way to give anything less. The view is great, but I would rather just go to "Cliff House" (A few yards away) for a great dinner and view rather than an expensive, dump diner.
author: ELIZABETH H.

description: This is a cozy spot (dated but in a charming way), perched on the edge of the cliff, offering sweeping vistas of the ocean rocks and Sutro Baths below.  Based on the view alone this would be a 5-star rating. However (yes, there is a however), the service was decent but nothing to write home (or Yelp) about.  The food was okay, but overpriced for what it was and definitely not enough for leftovers.  I guess I'll let them slide a little here because of the amazing location, which should come at a premium.  Lastly, they don't take credit or debit cards (maybe that's part of the "dated" theme) but they do have an ATM on the premises.  Not sure if the ATM charges an exorbitant fee and if it's another money making trap, because luckily it was one of those rare times when I carried enough cash on me, but do yourself a favor and also carry some cash when you visit.  All in all, this is a one-of-a-kind gem worth your patronage.  Just set your expectations high for the vistas but not too high for the food.
author: Hugo B.

description:
Oh my God I love this place. Me & my boyfriend started going here last January and by the second visit they knew us (I think it was because of my particularly loud dress choices) and now we're always greeted warmly and somehow always end up getting a choice booth, even if we do have to wait a few minutes on busy weekend mornings. 

I LOVE the crew. Whether it's the prototypical veteran diner waitresses or their cute jailbait successors, they're all sweet and efficient. The view is sublime and calming, the food is pretty good, and I love the ambience. I drive by it every day on my way to work and wistfully wish it were open for dinner (they close at 4 Sun-Thurs, 6 on Fri and Sat I think). 

WHen you go, be sure to grab a copy of the paper menu and read the history of the place printed on the back. It's an awesome story of a Greek family whose held onto the place for generations. 
May I recommend the magnifique French burger? It's so fat that I always end up bringing half of it home to the Chihuahuas - unless my boyfriend gets to it first. 

My only complaints: 1. They should take credit cards (it's cash only), and 2. They should offer white/New England clam chowder (currently they only offer red/Manhattan). But with so much else to offer, who can complain?
author: Cake M.

description:
Louis': simple, unpretentious, good food.  Gorgeous views.  Cash ONLY.  So much better than the scary Art Deco Cliff House.  Went for dinner on a Tuesday not long before they closed, and it was quiet and not too crowded.  

Very (most?) important, because you don't have a lot of choices in that area: bathrooms are clean.
author: diana s.

description:
The stars are strictly for the view. I wish I had ordered the breakfast items, as the dinner food was strictly sub-par. I couldn't decide if I had eaten these in a hospital cafeteria or my Jr.high cafeteria. Either way, no bueno. 

The 'dinner salad':iceberg, 2 slices of tomatos and a smattering of canned kidney beans. French fries: frozen, and not even crispy. Reminded me of oven-baked ones when Aunt Ethel is trying to lose weight. Chili cheeseburger: Costo/Sysco frozen patty covered with canned Costo/Sysco chili and grated cheese. Ugh.

However, my vanilla milkshake was thick and tasty. Service was fast.

The bill for two (we ate identical meals):$42.00. My friend never questions food bills, but this time he did. Since we paid $11.00 for those crappy salads, he was pissed. The topper for me was when the kid/waiter replied with a weak smile, 'Yeah, it's kind of a tourist trap'.

My tip reflected that of a Midwestern tourist with a weak smile.
author: Rene D.

description:
Fellow SF Native Rosie S. recently included Louis' on her "Old School SF" List and I thought it was high time to share this gem with anyone who hasn't been here.  The food here is whatever (does that mean I'm not allowed to give 5 stars?) and I must admit I've only been here for breakfast.  The experience of Louis' is one in a million.  This is a family restaurant with excellent service.  They are also very good about serving the food quickly and turning over tables in reasonable time.  You can eat breakfast food anywhere, but you might as well do so perched on top of a cliff with expansive ocean views as far as you can see.  A cup of coffee always tastes better while experiencing some scenery.  

It can get pretty crowded on the weekends, but believe me, I've spent quite a few mornings here and still gotten a window seat without a long wait.  On a nice day, I often take the opportunity to check out Fort Miley or walk down to Sutro Baths.  

You will get the ultimate experience here on a beautiful day.
author: Kerry D.

description:
The story here is the patty melt.

Never mind completely that this is essentially a diner hanging off a cliff overlooking the beautiful expanse of the Pacific.

But seriously, great view & solid, down-home greasy spoon food. The type of place you'd be more likely to find somewhere on Route 66. Definitely a great place to take friends or family visiting from out of town.
author: Pete J.

description:
EWWWWWWWWWW!

Yeah yeah, great views.  But food poisoning is not worth it, is it?

Service was not amazing, as some people on this Yelp page have said (for some strange reason) - it was very perfunctory.

The food is just downright awful, and add to that the fact that people get sick here and you've got a 1-star situation.
author: Jeremy L.

description: Bad food.  Sub-par service.  Great location!
author: Genevieve G.

description: Now this place has character; beautiful view and good food - considering this is a road side shake (in all fairness). Supposedly various celebrities come here (don't celebrities go every where once), so I can't confirm that. I recommend going here, but bring cash, they don't accept cards.
author: Alldaron K.

description:
When I first moved back to the West Coast, one of the first things I needed was a view of the Pacific.  Not knowing San Francisco geography particularly well, I drove west until I no longer could--and just as I approached the ocean--my long-lost Pacific Ocean!--I saw a tiny little restaurant perched on the side of a cliff with windows covering almost every wall and a line extending out the door.

This was Louis'.  On my first few visits, I ordered the same thing after waiting about 15 minutes for one of the tables at the window:  Sausage & cheese omelette, side of hash browns, earl grey tea.   

In true diner style, Louis' omelettes use American cheese & those frozen hash brown shreds.  The entire plate is plain, simple, greasy, cheesy, and fried.  

Although the prices seemed a little steep for diner breakfast (about $10 a person), I wasn't there for the food.  I was there for a nearly 180-degree view of Seal Rock & the Pacific Ocean.  

It's been a year since my first visit.  So, last week, I went back, but for lunch.  I ordered a cheeseburger with a side of fries and SWEET JESUS am I glad I did.  I knew the burger would be solid when the waitress asked me how I wanted it cooked.  The menu specifically warns you that eating undercooked meat may cause illness, but I've never come across a diner serving anything but a well-done burger. 

Of course, I wanted it medium-rare.  And it actually WAS medium-rare.

Moreover, the pink-inside, charbroiled-on-the-outside burger struck me on three fronts:

(1) It was delightfully salted and tasted of meat PLUS seasonings, not just meat,
 (2) It was greasy enough to make the toasted bun just a little damp, but dry enough to drip only a little meat-ketchup-mayo-mustard juice on my fingers as I went in for each bite, and
(3) It smelled like what a Whopper would smell like if it really was flame-broiled and made fresh.  

As for the fries, I hate to admit it--because the burger was so damn good--but they lacked pizzazz.  Needed salt or skins or something. But frankly, I barely noticed.
author: Ann M.

description:
Like everyone says, the view is the sole reason to visit this place. Unless you like very plain and simple diner food.  I think our conversation was disturbing the tourists...

But it is what it is and the wait and cost is much less than the competition for this vantage point.
author: Aaron W.

description:
yeah.. this place is just kinda cool!

A friend took me here prolly 10-ish years ago....

its really simple.... diner food... pie, hot choc... burger... fries...  but my favorite is... the iced-tea.... yeah.. I know it's out of syrup or something.. .but for some reason.. I always think of this place and iced-tea.  The food isn't nearly as good as the views... its actually not THAT bad to get to this place...and the lot is right across the street(but watch the crossing).

so it might not be hard to get to this place as in "the last mile" but as you can see from the map, it's obviously not real convenient to get to either, which makes stops by here rare and precious.

Hopefully you don't get seated by the bathrooms... that is an area for improvement.  I've never actually gone into them, but I have "experienced" them if you know what I mean.... its a small place.  

CASH ONLY!!!!!
author: Eric K.

description:
Starting with the fact that it was a gorgeously clear day, I'm giving this fun little diner-y joint 2 stars right off the bat. Another star for smelling like a diner, and for being non-assuming and unpretentious. Oh crap... only one star left.  Here goes.

I would highly, highly recommend the "2 eggs and hamburger patty." It comes with hash browns (that have been bathed in buttery goodness and grilled to golden perfection) and an English muffin.  And do you know what I did? Of course you don't... I'm the one writing this review.  Well, I put the burger patty on my English muffin and had a good linner. Or, lunner.  Dunch?  In point of fact, the burger patty was of such diameter that I had to carve about a third of it off one side in order to fix reasonably well on the muffin.  

The service was friendly and actually, quite good, which I was surprised about.  Make this your casual dunch or linner stop and you won't be sorry.
author: Rob W.

description:
okay, this is a diner that has been around for the 30s. It is NOT fine dining.  But how can you beat the views of waves crashing on a gorgeous sunny day?  And the waitstaff is so friendly. Our wait was only 25 minutes.  We got your basics: decent, strong coffee while we waited, cheese/ham omlette, french toast. Cured my hangover, while enjoying the views.
Great, relaxed place with incredible views. That view is why I will always love san francisco.
author: Nima K.

description:
I've been running by Louis' for about 3 years now since I pass it on my normal jogging route. Everytime I pass by it, I see crowds of people waiting outside. On occassion, there's even a nice, smoky aroma drifting out. However, in spite of all these good signs, I had never gone inside until last Sunday.

First of all, let me say that the restaurant is rather small, which might account for the crowds outside. Another reason might be the superior views of the cliffs, the ocean and the baths that are offered by the window and booth seats. And now that I think about it, the wonderful views are probably the only reason people come here (and keep coming back). The food is strict diner fare.  It's much like stuff you'd find at a Mel's Drive-In or Denny's even. It's nothing really special and nothing that'll really bring people back. I mean, I can hardly imagine anyone saying, "Louis' has the best toast, let's go back!"

With that said, the turkey breast sandwich I had was alright, even if it was a bit heavy on the mayo. Furthermore, I do have to compliment the wait staff, who were attentive and friendly. So even though the food is diner, there really isn't anything wrong with that, unless you're expecting some gourmet menu. And if you were, you probably wouldn't be going to Louis' anyways.
author: Philip W.

description:
Louis', you broke the heart I left in San Francisco.

The only reason that this place is getting three stars from me is because it *is* a rare vestige of old school San Francisco.  My grandmother used to take me out here on the 38 for root beer floats.  So they get a star for nostalgia's sake.

I treated myself to a breakfast here about a year ago and was shocked at the prices.  I ordered a bacon and cheese omelet (there weren't a lot of choices) which put  me out $11.  $2 more for a cup of non-fancy joe.  
When the omelet came, I discovered the cheese was plastic--Kraft singles or the Sysco version probably.  I'm not usually a food snob, but for $11, I expect real cheese, please.

The waitress was very nice and attentive, but apparently Louis' is preying on wealthy tourists.  

Next time I'm going to the Seal Rock Inn for breakfast.  Sure, it's not fancy, but the view is almost as good and the food is both better and much more reasonably priced.
author: Jen D.

description: We were headed to the coast last week when we encountered this little gem.  Exactly what we were looking for for breakfast on my sons birthday.  It was a Monday morning and we waited about 2 minutes for the most spectacular booth I think I've ever sat in.  Corner window with a beautiful view of the ocean.  Pancakes, potatoes, toast, etc., was good.  I'm not a big foodie but I liked it.  The price seemed very reasonable despite a few reviews I've seen on this board.  My only complaint is it's cash only, luckily we had enough.  There's a ATM there but as you all know that will add $5 to your breakfast once the ATM and your bank have their say.
author: Scott D.

description:
+:
this place is adorable.
this place has amazing service.
this place has the best view of the ocean and the sutro baths.
this place is one of the only true longstanding diners in the city.

-:
this place is cash only. (but don't fret! they have an atm machine inside!)
this place is a long wait and gets busy fast.
this place is blah food. blah blah blah. whine whine.
this place is still on the spectrum of fair, but slightly overpriced for what it is.

i've been here twice, once for breakfast and once for lunch. lunch was a bit better, but even still, the view is too good to miss. i know that we'll be back.
author: Tara T.

description: LOVED the views & the food was good here too.  Can't wait for them to reopen asap after the re-model!!
author: Andrea V.

description: My wife & I have been going to Louis' for 30 years. We loved the place, especially Rosie the waitress. But last week I ordered a cheeseburger which was definitely tiny & the fries were totally blah. The roll was hard & cold & the fries were tepid. At least my root beer float was great!
author: Ngam C.

description:
I visited Louis' on a beautiful Thursday afternoon. Three friends and myself were in search of a restaurant with a calming view and comfort food, and Louis' filled both of those needs. 

As most other writers have pointed out, you go here for the view, but really, the food was pretty good. It's diner food and atmosphere to be sure, but if you want the fancy goods, go down the road to the Cliff House.

I had a burger and fries, which were quite tasty. My friends chose "dinners", fried shrimp and fish and chips. The shrimp were a bit over-fried, but that was the only complaint. I was surprised the salads served with their meals included chickpeas. Everything was fairly inexpensive, though I specifically remember my burger and fries cost $8.95; which is a bargain considering that I got to watch a beautiful sunset and spend some time with friends. (When the hell did I get so sappy!?)
author: Lara L.

description:
I had an omelet/hash/pancakes and it was decidedly pretty good. Service was prompt, we got seated pretty quickly, and of course, the view is unbeatable. 

It's not the best thing EVAR, but very nice :)
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Louis' is a great place to take out-of-towners and impress them with the view definitely.  It has very consistent food but nothing to rave about.  The person I was with ordered an omelet that came with American cheese in it.  I'm sorry to be a snob, but you shouldn't put American cheese in an omelet, it messes with the consistency plus it tastes funkay.

You are definitely paying for the view and the service.  The people there are nice and friendly, definitely making you feel at home.  It's really easy to get to.  The 38 goes right there, so you don't even have to drive.

They don't take credit cards either, so watch out.
author: Ryan S.

description:
2 stars for the view, 0 stars for the food, staff, and prices.  Can't wait to see a new restaurant in this space, as long as it's cheaper than the Cliff House.

FYI, the hours Yelp has are wrong.  They're only open till 4:30pm on weekdays, and 6pm on weekends.  You're out of luck if you want to enjoy the sunset here.
author: Kevin O.

description: Went there for lunch today.  The young hostess pointed me to the table where we would be seated.  After the previous diners left, she cleared the table but didn't wipe it down,  and placed the silver ware on the unwiped table. Before she brought us to the table I watched her flick a piece of food off the table. When we were brought to the table, the table still had dried food on it and I asked the hostess to wipe the table down.  She reluctantly dabbed at the corner of the table and before I could ask her to wipe the entire table surface she took off.  It wasn't until mid meal was I able to get a waiter to complain about the table surface and he wiped down the table for us.  I complained to the Manager about the hostess' conduct and she explained it was her niece.  To her credit, the Manager listened to our complaint and apologized.
author: Dolly R.

description:
It was a sunny Saturday morning and the views were spectacular.  We went here with a group of 4 and the wait was about 10 minutes.  This is a great place to go when you are hungover and need some good comfort food to be in your tummy.

It's reasonably priced and has the basics when it comes to food.  It's Cash ONLY, so be prepared.
author: Dan D.

description:
This is the kind of diner that of course is only good for the obvious reasons. It's in San Francisco, It sits alone in a Landmark area, and has a gorgeous view of the Pacific.

Everytime I go it's only with one other person which is why the service is better that way. If you have a big group waiting for a table next to the window then you might find yourself waiting a while. Just keep it simple since it is a simple place and sit at the counter. The waitresses are all very nice and cute which is a plus.

If you are spending the morning at Ocean Beach with your mom or a good friend then stop, sit, and enjoy. I used to eat here every Saturday morning with my mom which is another reason I give it four stars.
author: Jason M.

description:
A great treat.  Located right on the coast, we sat in a booth that overlooked the deliriously gorgeous pacific ocean.  We were there for breakfast, so we got the usual breakfasty type foods.  It was all quite good.  Not ground-breaking. But the service was prompt and friendly.  We really loved the view, though. That prompts me to give 4-stars instead of 3.  It was very romantical.

I think the people who rate this restaurant down are spoiled by the gorgeous views and delicious foods of San Francisco. Perhaps they operate on a different scale of things... But for my palette and for what I like, I really enjoyed this place. And it was a very memorable breakfast experience.
author: Danny P.

description:
What can I say, I love this little place. If you can get the corner booth with friends, you have a two-wall view of the ocean below (as long as it's not really foggy). The prices have gone up a little bit, but that's happening everywhere. 

The food here is decent, not great, but decent. The reason people eat here is because of the friendly waitstaff and great views. I felt very much at home with the very friendly man working behind the bar, and hope he never quits!

It's one of my favorite places to go for a late lunch while fighting off a bad hangover.
author: Aaron P.

description: Louis' sticks to the basics and does it well.  Parking was easy.  There is a free parking lot across the street and another one up the hill.  I had a cup of their clam chowder and a cheesburger.  I didn't had to wait for a booth by the window. Service was excellent with constant refills of my soda.  I will come back again... on a weekday of course, to avoid the weekend tour buses.
author: Jeff H.

description: This is an affordable diner that I honestly have eaten here once in my 20 yrs of living in the Outer Richmond.  I ordered a tuna sandwich with fries.  It was okay, nothing special about the food other than its location and view of the ruins of the Sutro baths.  Its a old historic place about to fall off the cliff.  I hope it stays around but its fighting gravity!
author: S F.

description: Great view, reasonable price, excellent service & good food.  We found Louis by accident when our regular breakfast place "Beach Chalet" was completely booked.  Been coming here for Sunday breakfast since as it's cozy and a great place for our family to gather on Sunday mornings from time to time.
author: Kmaintl L.

description:
A great place to come if you want really consistent diner food coupled with an amazing view. Also a good standby for breakfast if you want to go to the cliffhouse but the wait is too long.

This is good old fashioned diner food, french toast, pancakes, omlettes, burgers, sandwiches, fries. Friendly service and a regular spot for lots of locals.

Minus two stars because for what the food is it's a bit pricey and they also have bad hours. Closed by 4 or 5 pm every day.
author: Josh J.

description: What can I say about this place that hasn't been said already?  Not much.  The waitresses acted like they didn't want to be there and the bathroom is a tight fit for fat people. We each had a BLT and fries.  Food was hot and crispy, but pretty standard diner fare.  The prices were a little high for a diner, but we were happy to pay extra for the view.   The view was phenomenal.   I wish that I could have been on this stretch of land 50 years ago when there were bars and other casual restaurants built on this bluff.  It must have been amazing.  After our lunch, we walked down to the old Sutro bath site and explored the ruins.  If you go for food, bring cash, and walk off your meal down at the baths....
author: Peter R.

description: Wow! I feel like this place hasn't changed in 50 years - decor and all. It's like stepping back in time. The high point of this restaurant is the lovely views of the ocean and Sutro Baths. The food and service were about what I'd expect at a diner. Tasty and pleasant but not much more.
author: Kevan M.

description:
food-very american
view-absolutely excellent
prices-not bad considering the location
author: kiki b.

description: I love this place! I use to come here on the weekends with my family for breakfast. Its a small little restaurant with a GREAT VIEW of the ocean. Service is great! food isnt bad at all and its an all around nice place to eat. Havent been here in YEARS though, I should really pay Louis a visit with my mom sometimes soon.
author: Daniel S.

description:
The food is overpriced but equivalent to what you'd find in most diners.
The view however is SPECTACULAR!
'Nuff said.

That should be all you need to know about this place but since I see my fellow Yelpers unable to adequately describe this place I'll continue.
Unless you're 'touched in the head' you probably will have figured out that this place is not like most other restaurants you find in the area. The fact that its clearly located inside of a park should tell you not to expect prices competitive with McDonalds for a $2.99 sausage and eggs combo. This restaurant operates as a park concession inside a National Park folks. That's why you're paying so much and complaining about the food being overpriced. But the food isn't bad and in some cases you're paying less that what you might pay at the restaurant located on the rim of the Grand Canyon or at the fancy hotel restaurant located inside of Yosemite Park. Those places operate as national park concessionaires too and thats why the prices there are higher than you'd expect. Its not rocket science, but alas so many fellow reviewers don't get it.
In other words, this is the kind of place you take out of towners or tourists go to because you want to show them an amazing view of the coastline only minutes away from Metro SF and hey, you can sit and have pancakes and a cup of coffee when the weather outside is chilly as it so often is in SF (even in summer!) And you know what, its worth the extra ten bucks! So get over yourselves. There are plenty of overpriced restaurants all over SF that don't have anywhere near as good a view. Some places you go to because the food is a good value or the chef is amazingly creative, or the place is closeby and convenient. This is none of those but its still something special that San Franciscans get to brag about.
Anyone taking the time to read the menu could figure this all out because they practically shout out to you 'We are a operating as a National Park Concessionaire! Sorry the prices are so high!' They also have a fairly interesting history which you can read about on their website. The same family really has been operating out of this location for over 75 years even before the park existed. At one time they probably did serve better scratch made food back when they owned the building and could probably afford to offer food at more competitive prices. Today, lets just be glad you can still sit a few hundred feet from the crashing tide enjoying a bowl of chili or oatmeal or fish sandwich.
Bonus points for being open early enough to watch the sun rise over the crashing surf!
author: R S.

description: Breakfast for two $27 and tip took to $30.  Frozen Potatoes baked not good.  Sausage cold and service uninspired.  Will not go back.  Used to go regularly.  No more.  View is great.
author: Joseph A.

description:
Wow......breakfast with a spectacular view....
the chesse omelet was great
author: chris j.

description: This is likely my favorite place to have brunch in the bay area. It's not really just about the food, it's the great view and the unpretentious diner experience.
author: CM P.

description: My man and I come here for breakfast/lunch almost every weekend, especially when it's really stormy outside.  We like to sit at the counter and veg out, read the paper, stare at each other or check out other customers.  I crave their hashbrowns, waffles, pancakes, fries and tuna sandwiches on a regular basis.  The staff is always very nice.  The view is great!
author: Mieke V.

description:
The food was alright but service just really blew. A party of four of us came in on a Sunday morning at about 10;30 and we waited for about 50 minutes while they let numerous parties of 2 before and after us on the list go ahead. I am sorry but taking in two parties of 2 and filling in 4 seats of the 6 seat tables rather than one part of 4 and one party of 2 is just plain bad business. 

P.S.  Considering what we paid for the food, it totally blew that we were given fake cheese-Velveeta in the omelet.
author: Eugenia S.

description:
Best Milkshakes in the City of San Francisco.  My Dad has been taking me there since I was 3 and the place has always been fun, friendly and the food has always been tasty.  

I must gush over these milkshakes, they are amazing, thick, creamy, never too chocolaty  and they always give you enough for at least two glasses.  they also never ruin them by putting whipped cream on the top.  

I admit I haven't sampled too much of the menu.  I always get a grilled cheese sandwich, most of the wait-staff knows that as my usual.  

It will always be the best hang out for me and my Dad, and you get a great view of the ruins of Sutro Bath and the ocean.  

A beautiful piece of San Francisco History.
author: Amy P.

description: This place is so not worth the wait! Service is horrible... Food over priced...we spent $40 on an omelette n burger... They use Kraft cheese for the omelette (yuck...and they dont even tell you) and the burger was dry with no favor. We waited 45 minutes to get our food and it was not worth the wait. Go elsewhere!!! Only thing good was the view and you can get that for free outside the restaurant! Trust me dont go there you will be disappointed!!!
author: Maria P.

description:
This was everything I wanted. We got lucky and had zero wait for lunch today. Gorgeous 90 degree clear day. Unbeatable view from almost every seat in the joint.
I ordered a chicken breast sandwich and a hamburger steak with grilled onions.  The chicken was char grilled, super tasty and moist, and the burger was juicy and very good quality meat.  Add super friendly service and reasonable prices ($30 for two people) that's 5 stars in my book.
Will go back !
author: Mattman J.

description: I've been here twice. I had breakfast both time. It was a long wait but the staff is really friendly. One of the cooks chimed in during a story I was telling a date. The cook was amazed that I had such a crazy trip to New Zealand. I had an omelet one time and steak and eggs the other. Its typical diner food. Nothing wow, but its a cozy place with a nice view.
author: Annie P.

description: the renovated and remodeled Louis' has reopened and it's as good as ever, even if a little more expensive ... food is still top rate and employees efficient and friendly ... two window booths were sacrificed in order to upgrade bathroom ... still offers best ocean view dining other than the Cliff House at much more affordable prices ... no trip to San Francisco is complete without a meal at Louis'
author: Jack W.

description: I won't echo everybody and proclaim, "Spectacular view !" b/c no shit Sherlock, we all know that. I will say that the breakfast was yummers (sunny side up, hash browns, bacon, surprisingly good drip coffee -- cardiac arrest oblivion) and the lunch I had on another visit was really tasty (burger, fries, diet soda, ha ha I saved 140 calories right there). service was pleasant and courteous. my only small gripe: leaving the place and smelling like a heaping stack of fried potatoes. I always wanna smell good but not deep-fryer good
author: Prima D.

description: If Victorian ruins and art-deco renovations aren't doing it for ya, or the Cliff House's myriad dining areas are just too confusing, try Louis' for some good old-fashioned 70's diner action.  All the browns and reds you need (I especially dig the floor), and the same great views.  It's very basic diner fare: omelettes and griddles, burgers, grilled cheese, fish & chips (I can heartily recommend the fried prawns, by the way).  Don't think that this will be a quiet, uncrowded alternative to the Cliff House though: it's small and very popular, so I recommend stopping in after 2:30 or so to avoid the lines.  You should be able to time it just right after a nice walk around Lands End, Sutro Heights or Ocean Beach.
author: Wes M.

description: Great view!  But you knew that.  Took a while to get a seat.  Limited seating but most with great view.  Diner style.  Food was good.  Cost was a bit high due to location.  Popular spot.
author: Bob W.

description: Great spot. The views are amazing and the food is good. I had a fantastic scramble. Pretty busy with tourists, but I'm a local and I'll definitely be back.
author: Theodore N.

description:
My mom has lived in SF since she was a small one and she has never eaten here.  When she was little she didn't go here because her family couldn't afford to eat out.  Now she doesn't go here because there are nicer places to go.  
I think you go here to get nostalgic. I am not sure what you'd be nostalgic about-especially if you haven't been around as long as Louis' family has.  I mean, really, what the hell was I doing in the 30s?? Still this place I guess reminds me of my grandma. She liked diner's.  And it reminds me of my time in the 70s (when the second remodel occurred)  when the favorite colors were in the yellow/orange range.  Aww,. those were good times....in my pre existence life!  Somehow those colors are a good contrast to the green hills outside.  
The service was just OK.  The food was just OK.  The story of Louis and his Greek origins, etc is fun.  
A good movie could be filmed here...not sure which one but I can see it now...
I can tell you people would be smoking though.  And even though it's cash only they don't allow cigarette smoking which would really make it genuinely old school.  You don't get the feel that the people are pretentious or up tight.  But along those lines you don't get the feeling that they especially care either way...
author: Lauren S.

description: I love going to Louis' for Sunday breakfast.  I think the food is far less greasy than Mel's.  The menu is pretty standard and I normally get a grilled cheese with soup but when I can get there early enough I get pancakes.  There's usually a wait but if you don't mind sitting at the counter the wait is short.  It's a mild tourist crowd but I don't mind it.  The wait staff is pleasant and I love the 70's decor.  Walk off your breakfast at any of the surrounding parks.  There are four within blocks of Louis'.
author: Joni S.

description: I wasn't going to review this place because I don't want anyone else going here and taking up space, but since it already's been mentioned.... we love. disclaimer, Louis is run by old friends, Bill & Tom Hontalas who inherited the operation from their parents. I was in Cub Scouts with Tom and went to High school with Bill, and they run a quality operation. It is bare-bones in decor and specializes in simple breakfasts, burgers and a few other dishes. Louis' is a GREAT place to take people from out of town, killer view and no snootiness, so anyone can feel comfortable here. Parking is easy and kids do great too.
author: jim b.

description: A greasy spoon with the best views in the world.  you feel like you're perched on the cliff, just about to take off over the ocean.  The food is awesome - greasy fried breakfast products.  for those of you particular about your greasy spoon hash browns, they have the shredded kind.  they have the good diner hot chocolate from the machine.  the service is fast and efficient and the prices are ridiculously low.  did i mention the view?  really, there's no reason not to try louis'.
author: Bryna M.

description: If your not in the mood to splurge at Sea Cliff or Beach Chalet, go to Louis.With just as a great a view as the other places including the burnt remains of the old Sea Cliff bath houses, they serve American breakfast food. Good service and not too pricey. never had to wait more than 10 minutes for a great Ocean Beach experience
author: Dennis L.

description: A decent diner with a much more than decent view, nice service and tiny bathrooms.  Excellent spot for pre or post Sutro Bath ruins adventure.
author: Derek D.

description: The view is great but not the wait. After you wait for over 35 minutes, you expect a place to have the decency to have the best possible grade of meat for your cheeseburger but this was not the case. I was too starving to send it back and you never know what they will do to the next thing they send out to you. Dumb move. I should have sent it back and kept the fries to tide me over as I waited. The meat just did not taste right so I think I will stick to breakfast when I go to Louis' from now on.
author: Lisa J.

description:
where else in the city can you get a patty melt and look out onto the ocean like this?  i mean, its a little spendy for a greasy diner, but you know, considering the view, and the cost of the place next door, this place is a total bargain.

if you have out of town guests and don't want to deal with cliff house, this place is so there for you.
author: Steve S.

description: Great view of the Pacific Ocean and not paying the prices of Cliff House restaurant for breakfast/brunch. Simple, no hassle tiny place, worth the wait but food-wise, it's the likes of Denny's but slightly better quality.
author: Yan M.

description: This place is so lame.  Don't be fooled by the view.  If you are having breakfast, there is better food for cheaper about ten blocks in.  Get coffee and walk around the coast.  If you are having lunch, go to a deli and eat on the beach.
author: Patrick A.

description:
Disclaimer - we did not eat here, though we tried.  

We come in and wait.  Waitresses look over at us, and then furtively down at the ground and hurry away.  More than five minutes later, what appears to be the "head" waitress asks us if we are waiting for  a window.  Well, we tell her, we are just waiting for a seat.  Maybe 10 minutes, she says and disappears.  More customers trickle in, they are not helped either, so we become the defacto maitre de and explains the situation to them.  A table is vacated, but not bused.  I think about busing it myself.  All this time, we are availed of the opportunity to observe the goings on of the kitchen and servers.  And they didn't look up to snuff - it looked like a real cluster.  So, we decided, rather than be seated and get more and more frustrated with the service, better to just leave.  Two stars for the view though.  The food looked like typical diner food - greasy burgers and fries.  Oh, and cash only.

Oh, and about the shakes that Bevy mentions as being good - I heard the waitress telling a party that they were too busy to make shakes so they couldn't have one.  So, maybe they are good, but don't come when it's busy.
author: Jeremy S.

description: One star for the view and one star because that is the minimum.  This place is standard diner fare, but if you've been on the beach for a while and need a bite it will do.  The chowder was nothing special and the fish and chips were ok.  I get the feeling this place might be better for breakfast food.  Shakes looked good too.
author: Tim S.

description: Cute little place to warm up with a cup of coffee and some french fries and look at the ruins. They get an extra star for a pretty kick-ass Milkshake! Authentic diner, unauthentic prices!
author: Eric I.

description: An old-style family diner, situated above the ruins of the old Sutro Baths.  Food is traditional diner fare, satisfying as only diner food can be, and the views are exceptional.  Even better, if you're lucky enough to get Hazel as a waitress, this American original will tempt you with other diners' food, tell you in no uncertain terms what you ought to order, and generally make you feel that you've stepped through a time warp to an earlier era.  There's often a wait, especially if you want one of the window tables with a view of the Baths, but it's well worth it.  And when you're done, wander down to the rocks and wonder why someone doesn't rebuild the darn thing!  The ruins are so cool, but a working revival of the Sutro Baths would be even cooler!
author: Tim O.

description: We lived in the Avenues right beside Louis' back in the late 80s.  We went there at least 3 times per week.  And every time we visit SF we make it a point to hit it at least once.   You got it all here....friendly ambience,  good food at reasonable prices,  and a view to die for.  Just a great ol' diner.  As for me and all of my friends and family....we've never once had a bad experience at Louis'.  I have no idea why there are ANY negative reports on this lovely little cafe.  Spoiled brat perfectionism is my guess....LOL.
author: Geary W.

description: Old school SF.  Consistently friendly, better than average diner chow.  Terrific views and house made items (like Manhattan clam chowder) are a great start to the day.  Folks who don't dig the nostalgia won't like the food as much.
author: Stefan A.

description: This place is definitely in a time warp, and I much prefer it to the boring renovation of the Cliff House.  It's such a cozy little diner, and you can't beat the view.  Prices are very reasonable, but there's not much of a selection for vegetarians.  Ask them to add tomato to the grilled cheese, and they'll be happy to oblige.
author: Andi T.

description:
sometimes you just want an old school diner meal.  throw in a view of the ocean, and well, i'm ok with it.  

lots of tourists flock to louis' place.  it's been around since the 40s, and you can feel the history when you're there.  basic diner food.  burgers, breakfast, a cup of joe, and helpful service.

greasy.  but good.
