and a great place to eavesdrop on tourists from all over the world.  no, i'm not a stalker.  peoplewatcher, yes.  stalker? well. whatever.

i did hear a guy pseudo propose to his lady.  he kinda threw it on the table like "would you ever consider."

i mean, that's kinda cool.  

the two german guys sitting at the bar were not amused. they were probably upset we weren't all wearing turtlenecks.
author: Kimberly K.

description: Reasonably cheap diner food, but as everyone has mentioned the real reason to go here is the gorgeous view of the water. Due to a mixup we ended up with free sourdough bread that was delicious.
author: Kimberley D.

description:
this is a place that a native has to visit once in a while to appreciate how she's a lucky girl to live in such a beautiful city. this was my second visit in 15 years. i'm not that old.

ms and i had brunch here this morning before hitting the land's end trail. we carbo loaded on two orders of short stacks and one order of scrambled eggs and sausage with hash browns and english muffins. i know it's only a three mile walk, but it was all pretty good. 

we sat at the counter because it was taking too long to get a window seat. the counter was really fun because we got to know leon. he's the nice guy who gets you hot coffee and tells you funny stories about his hood. he lives in the TL. i work in the TL. when he's at work, he "dresses down" because if you saw him all blinged out, one of his TEN gold rings might blind as he pours your coffee. he hides them on a chain behind his apron. it's cool!

and since it was SUPER busy this holiday morning it was fun to hear the waitresses gripe about the annoying tables. muwahahahaha! 

decent food and an experience that you have to try at least once in your life.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
the food's nothing to be like wow about, but with a view like that, does it even matter?  and unfortunately, not as cheap as you might expect ($6.75 for 2 eggs, an english muffin, and hash browns; $2.05 for tea), but again--the view.  and booth seats.  i love booth seats.

p.s. my dad begs to differ about the deliciousness of the food--he loves the pancakes because they're still good even when they're cold.
author: Janice C.

description: The view gets a star, and another star just because giving one for this place does not seem completely fair.  What a disappointment though!  They have a prime location and what I expected to see on the menu was not necessarily gourmet, but these guys are missing a major opportunity here.  What I expected to see was some ocean flare, ie SEAFOOD on the menu!  The best they had was Manhattan chowder and fish and chips!  That seems insane.  I think they need to look to some New England dives along the coast and do it up for some seafood kinda grub.
author: Jaime C.

description: They're obviously charging you for the view because the food is wholly unremarkable.  If you want good diner food, go to the Grubstake.  If you want to take in the view, skip this place and skip straight down to the beach or the ruins.
author: Frankie D.

description: 5 stars for the amazing view, 2 stars for the less-than-average but still edible greasy food.  3 stars for the service and friendly staff.  This review settles on a total of 4 stars, the place has great tourist appeal and I enjoy taking out-of-town guests there.
author: George K.

description: Cash only is OK for MacDonalds, but when you're asking a small group to fork over upwards of fifty dollars, it's tacky not to accept plastic, unless you expect your  patrons to be crack whores and drug dealers, peeling bills off a roll of C notes.  If anybody here in the restaurant is reading this as I'm typing, my apologies to table three - I'm not talking about you.
author: David H.

description: Went here for breakfast today after a long run and it really hit the spot!  Ordered the bacon and eggs, it came with tons of hashbrowns and an english muffin.  The bacon was delicious!
author: Joann P.

description: This is one of my favorite breakfast spots in the city. Sure it's small, but the views are huge. The food is always yummy -as is the staff. Sure tourists hit up the place too, but it's because it's so awesome!
author: Danni M.

description: Louis' is without a doubt one of my favorite destinations for breakfast or brunch in this whole city.  Perched on a cliff above the Sutro Baths with a view of Seal Rock and the towering Cypresses that crown Lands End there is a no more scenic restaurant in all the world to enjoy basic, traditional and exceptional tasting American style diner food.
author: Polynesian m.

description: The ocean view high above Sutro baths is amazing from this intimate diner. The place gets crowded for breakfast, so strut in early for a typical and hearty diner meal. Then proceed down to admire the gunk in the ocean eroded baths, hike around Sutro Heights, stroll through the Presidio golf course, and spend a day at the Legion of Honor. A perfect leisurely urban outdoor date.
author: Cathy H.

description: Underwhelming but nice staff.Had a Bacon cheeseburger for 9.75 that was pretty small and dry-for that price you would think it would be a better than average burger but..very basic and it seemed it was made by someone who didnt care to make it good.Plus the frys were of the siting under the heat lamp variety......dont know how you can make a bad burger but they did.
author: james m.

description: The view is better than the food, but the food doesn't kill you.  Good for Sunday morning hangovers and to talk about old San Francisco.
author: Hodie K.

description: Ok, so alot of people have issues with Louis, but honestly? It's my favorite breakfast/brunch place in San Francisco... My parents used to take me there when I was young, and it's still one of my favorite places to go... The views are amazing... The prices are cheap... I definately recommend it... Just don't go during busy times, or you get a shitty table with no view...
author: Lindsey S.

description:
I discovered Louis' on a run I was doing from Ocean Beach. I was only in mile 1 of 8 miles when I ran by this place and the smell coming from it at 8AM was amazing! So amazing that the next morning when my boyfriend suggested I choose the breakfast place I immediately said "the place I ran by yesterday morning!" 

We walked in and yes, it is a little outdated, but in a good way. It reminds me of when I was a kid, and the inside smells just as delicious as I had remembered. The views are amazing and the wait for a window table is a little longer (about 10 minutes) so we took a counter seat. The  food came within 10 minutes, and it was delicious! We both ordered omelette's...cooked perfectly, and their hashbrowns are cooked to perfection. Crispy on the outside (not burnt like some places) and soft on the inside. 

The servers are friendly and attentive, food is delicious and cheap, and the views are stunning.

Overall fantastic and I would definitely go there again.

My only complaint would be that they originally sat us at a table that was so close to the table next to it - the guys arm was on top of my hand practically. But, they moved us when asked.
author: Kelly K.

description: I used to love to go here when I was little.  The food is pretty good, at least it used to be (haven't been in a while).  What you really go for is the great views!  You can't beat them, especially considering the low cost of the food.  There used to always be these mounted policemen eating in there, it seemed like they never left!  Are they still there? Nine-year-old me recommends the milkshakes.
author: Mr. G.

description: i like the set up - being right on the cliff's edge and all.  However, by all means, don't go for the food.  It's not "bad", it's just not very good.  I had the chilly bowl- it was fine - tasted like canned chilly with a pile of onions and cheese on top - nice large piece of sourdough bread to go with.  My g/f had the waffle - thin - looked like it was once frozen, and some basic scramble.  customers are all tourists (for the most part).  Waitresses not too friendly - looked really stressed out - too much to answer a question without a quick unfriendly reply - looked annoyed and rushed (although they looked overstaffed).
author: Megan M.

description:
This place is a little far from home for it to be a regular haunt of mine, but I do like to eat lunch here after walking, running or biking the Battery and Lands Ends trail to Sutro Baths. The bacon and eggs with hash browns really hit the spot after a morning of walking.

Some of the food here can be a little generic, but the staff are always friendly and helpful and the prices aren't bad.
author: Martin A.

description: The view is gorgeous and the waitstaff are all friendly and seem to work hard while it's so busy.  Really want to support them because they're a family business around for so long, but the food and prices aren't worth it.
author: Ye W.

description: Great brunch spot on a cold sunny day. You feel like you're outside, but without the cold food yet still enjoy the sunshine. The food is okay, I've mostly had egg breakfasts here and they're attentive with coffee and such. The only downside? They only take cash. Being a credit card girl, I've had to mooch off friends on a few occasions. At least I didn't have to wash dishes in the kitchen.
author: Amy Y.

description: I have added this to my "must" visits whenever I'm in San Francsico.  I've not had lunch here so can't comment,  but breakfast at Louis' is terrific.  Eggs,  toast,  etc. cooked EXACTLY as you specify...breathtaking view of the water,  right over the ruins of the old Sutro Baths.  Always worth the wait,  and I hate to wait to be seated!     The world (and San Francsico) needs more places like this,  and fewer "cutting edge" SOMA rip-off dining "experiences."
author: Taylor B.

description: The food here is great but it's all about the location!  Beautiful view of the cliffs and Sutro Baths!  Wish they took cards but other than that it's a cute little diner by the sea!
author: Sean M.

description: It's not as cheap as Howard's but it is as greasy of a spoon. Plus, there's a view that only the Cliffhouse rivals. The wait is worth it and the hash browns are nothing special; in other words, perfect! Check it out.
author: David D.

description: Come here for the breathtaking views and the friendly service after exploring Land's end. Don't come here for the food, which is mediocre at best, and overpriced. If they could only figure that part out...
author: Ralphie K.

description: Old school burger kind of joint on the cliff, by the Cliffhouse.  Great view.  Super 70's.  It's been in the same family since the 30's.  If you're in the area, it's definitley worth checking out.  It's an out of date diner with some pretty good burgers, fries and tuna melts.  And it looks like they're breakfast menu is pretty good too.
author: Lauren M.

description: Great location.  The food is your standard greasy diner type food...but every once in awhile you need a good cheeseburger or BLT with a shake, right?  I just love eating there on a foggy sunday and then walking around the point towards the golden gate. Aaahh...
author: Angela T.

description: This wonderful little gem of a diner beats any view from the Beach Chalet or Cliff House. Started way back in 1937, the old-timey charm of this place is a nice departure from the standard Mel's Drive-in experience.
author: Jim S.

description: There isn't anything out of the ordinary on the menu -- it's 100% straight up diner food. We both had bacon burgers and they totally hit the spot. Thick & crispy bacon, crispy fries, groovy brick floors, a great view, and very friendly employees = 4 stars.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: If your looking for a great view of the Pacific, and the old Sutro Baths then this is the place to be.  I come here somewhat often as I live 10 blocks away and everytime I have never been dissapointed.  The service is great, the view is AMAZING, and their food is delicious.   I have never really been a breakfast person, but I do love their waffles and pancakes, and that is a plus for me.  I will say that the only con is that they take cash only.  But after living in San Francisco for three years now, it's something that you just get used to.  This is a great place to take visitors because of the stunning views.
author: Samantha R.

description:
breakfast time.  2 eggs, over easy or medium, potatoes and toast.
the old man and i sat at the counter because window seats are too scenic not to be taken.  the view, no matter where you sit is still great.  it overlooks the old sutro baths and a sweet lil cove that births pure and powerful blue and white crested swells that crash into the ruins of old san francisco.  the old run down parking lot that sits on the ridge of the cliff and land's end trail has been paved and expanded, so there is plenty of room to park now.  
the breakfast.  it was good and standard.  the service was great.  just a great lil greasy spoon joint that has not changed since the 70's.  i love the rust and red colored brick and ceramic mugs.  a creepy guy sat next to me and ordered decaf and jam packets so he could take his medicine.  he was creepy.  the waitresses were still nice to him.  i like that.  
thanks for reading!
author: yayoi s.

description: This place has got to be the Worst restaurant in the Best Location that I have ever experienced.  By far.  The menu is awful.  The menu gives only horribly basic dishes to choose from that even make your local everyday diner appear Dottiesesque.  Who ever wants to order an omelette with just ham (and eggs).  Is that really an omelette.  And then have a separate omelette dish with Ham and Cheese for $2 more.  And then have another separate dish called Eggs and ham.  This is the creativity we're talking about.  Then you get crazy and order the omelette with ham and cheese and the cheese ends up being 2 Kraft singles (or maybe it was some nacho cheese) slapped in the wedge of some eggs to form an "omlette."  Side orders included a half pound hamburger patty or a heated danish.  I passed by a couple on the way to the restroom that ordered a waffle and I swear it was a Leggo my Eggo waffle that I used to pop in the microwave.  Also, the men's bathroom is the tiniest bathroom that opens up immediately into a one toilet stall door that you have to sneak around to get into the stall.  Anyway, I know I'm being harsh here, but the food selection was amazingly basic and the food was far below average. The place does have an amazing view though with a ton of history and a very old school diner feel if you're looking for it.
author: Justin P.

description: I come here when I visit my grandmother, who lives in the outer sunset.  Just a jaunt up the coast, right next to the cliff house, is this wonderful little place.  I've not been to the new cliff house, but I have been to the Beach Chalet down the road, and quite frankly Louis' is my favorite.  The view is amazing, beginning with the remnants of the old bathhouse in the foreground, finishing with the Pacific Ocean and the northern coast.  Fare is good, tasty, American coffee shop food.  The coffee is good too.  I usually get a sandwich or a burger, which comes on a sliced French baguette and is really one of the tastiest burgers I've ever had.  The patty melt is really good too.  Wine and beer are available, cash only though, it's that old school, which is a little annoying too.  Otherwise, the prices are cheap and the view is fantastic.  Try this place, you won't regret it.
author: Christopher V.

description: I used to visit the Cliffhouse area, when the nickel arcade with the Laughing Sally and the black-and-white photo booths were still around. But after the Cliffhouse was rebuilt into something fancier, Louis' became a nice alternative to the newly rebuilt restaurant nearby. Inside you can still see remnants of an area that once had the Sutro Baths and Playland with its diner style seats and booths. Depending on where you sit, you get a nice view of the ocean. But due to the high number of tourists, expect to wait. The food is somewhat reasonable, nothing out of the ordinary, but still satiating. I did enjoy their breakfast omelette. It's always a plus when you can find a restaurant that serves breakfast at all hours of the day.
author: Rob N.

description:
I became the San Francisco touring master when a foreign visitor came to stay for 18 days.  On our visit to Ocean Beach, I noticed Louie's for the first time.  I'd usually take visitors to the Cliff House to do the Pacific Ocean-isn't it lovely-glass windows thing, but decided to check this diner out.  And that's right folks, it was a real diner!  Owned by a Greek family!  It was like I'd died and gone right back to New Jersey!  But with a turquoise ocean and the Sutro Baths instead of (insert NJ stereotype here, ie shopping mall).  
It wasn't the best grilled cheese I'd ever had, but hell, it was grilled cheese and I'd be hard pressed not to like that.  The decor is very orange and brown 70's style.  The wait for a table seemed like it might be long, but I was down with seats at the counter.  Parking was a bit of a hoopla.
Read the history on the back of the menu, if you can stop gazing out the window.  It's rather touching and slightly weepsome.
author: Maggie H.

description: It's a diner.  A diner with a great view and good service.  If you expect more than diner food you'll be disappointed. Someone said they were told by the waitress to go to Cliff House.  I love that so much.  Can you just imagine?  Smug twenty-something comes in asking for a Stella and a nice Vouvray....Flo tells 'em to go to Cliff House and kiss her grits on the way out.  I'm gonna make a special trip to Louis' tomorrow and leave Flo a fat tip.
author: Jason G.

description:
What a view!

Food's okay. Not bad, just kind of typical diner foods.

Bring cash moneys
author: Karen J.

description:
First thing that hits you is the view! 270 degrees of beach, rocky coast, massive freighters sailing under the Golden Gate, birds whirling against the blue ocean, the relics of the Sutro Bath just below you. Only the Carnelian Room can challenge this view IMHO.

My wife and I have had breakfast, brunch, and lunch at Louis' for almost 25 years (we live in Tres Pinos and manage our day in SF around eating here). Everything is filling, cooked just the way we requested it, very tasty. Constant drink refills, smiling waitresses, even a friendly table busser. It's a hometown diner with hometown folks.

Obviously avoid the noon-time rushes as there are only four booths and maybe four tables with a complete window view. I think the longest wait we have encountered has been less than five minutes. So go visit the Cal Academy of Sciences or the new De Young Museum, then pop into Louis' for a satisfying meal.
author: William M.

description: It's all about the view. The interior of this diner could be defined as 70's-tacky, but who cares when you're looking beyond to the Sutro Baths, the ocean and, if you are lucky, a spectacular sunset. The food is reasonably priced and tasty and typical of your usual diner fare. I had a cup of Manhattan clam chowder that was pretty small and left me lusting after my friend's hamburger, but next time, when I'm more set on a full meal, I'll try a burger. I haven't been to Cliff House yet, but I'm sure this place beats it for a view and is much more affordable.
author: Caitlin H.

description: any other diner offers the same food... great morning view and nice staff.  EXPENSIVE for a 3 egg omlette or waffle.
author: phill h.

description: This is a diner - not an elegant 5-star restaurant.  As diners go, the food is about as good as most of them (average fare), but the view of the ocean is the reason to go.  And like other diners, it's rather small, so if you pick noon on a weekend, you're gonna wait - especially for a table near a window.  On the plus side, the desserts are surprisingly good.  Does mid-afternoon pie and coffee strike your fancy?  This is the place to go.
author: Jak K.

description: BAD, DISGUSTING, GROSS, OVERPRICED, OVERRATED, UNFRIENDLY, DISAPPOINTMENT!! This place provided me with the worst dining experience I've had in the city.  My boyfriend, his brother (who is a butcher at wholefoods, and knows good seafood) and I all decided to check this restaurant off our to-eat lists.  My mother recommended the place, because she loved it back in the 70's.  The place looked like a funky mid-western mall dive of a restaurant, but we figured looks aren't everything.  unfortunately, we very soon realized we had made a bad choice by staying.  The service was slow and unfriendly, but WORST of all, the food was disgusting.  We ordered the prawns, fish and chips, double burger and shrimp cocktail.  We figured that because of the location next to the ocean, seafood was probably a safe bet.  WRONG.  The prawns were worse than fish sticks I had as a child, the fish and chips were soggy, and the double burger, tasted like is came from a fast food restaurant.  the french fries were the crinkle cut ones that come from a large freezer bag.  The prawns and fish were of the same frozen lineage, and the burger was so thin that it probably came pre-made....from costco.  The price for all dishes was around 16 dollars a piece.  Our total bill came to 80 bucks.  Really???  For frozen, disgusting food???  The waitress didn't ask how our meal was, which would have opened up the flood gates.  I'm sure she could guess based on the fact that we barely touched our plates.  I ate one prawn and then had to fill up on gross, frozen, though somewhat more edible french fries.  The view was nice, but the restaurant didn't make the view, they made the food.  I would have preferred fast food and a bench overlooking the ocean to this overated, overpriced, vomit-inducing hole of a crap shoot of a piece of shit restaurant.  DON'T GO HERE!!!
author: Jo B.

description: This is a diner indeed. Diners in my book cannot be "fine diners" because diner food is average, you've got the breakfast, the burgers...what else is new? I'll tell you what's new! Louis' has the friendliest service and amazing views.  Yes, the place is small, but if you are going to a diner this is the cutest one to go to.  There doesn't seem to be a high turn-around on the waitstaff, the people who work there have been doing it for years and are happy to be there. Isn't that refreshing? No? You...you don't care how long they've been working there? In that case you might care about the view. Clearer days are always better (duh), but you are on a cliff, overlooking the water, sutro baths, Marin....those are some top-notch views and they come complimentary with breakfast! I've only been a few times with friends that know this place well (it's a bit out of my way), but I just always feel so at home and comfortable here. It's a great place to start the day.
author: Aristocles P.

description: Went with a friend for breakfast.  Bacon and eggs.  Wanted crispy bacon, no such luck.  1/3 way thru meal, bit into something HARD.  Examined it, a piece of egg colored plastic.  Waitress offered new breakfast.  My appetite was gone.  She proceeded to still charge my friend her breakfast and me my O.J. and coffee! Owner would not come out of kitchen to apologize or make things right.  Old San Francisco my ass.  In old San Francisco (I know of what I speak, 60 yrs. here) the owner would have come out , said Breakfast (all of it) is on us, and we hope you'll be back.  And all would not only be forgotten, but they may have gotten a loyal customer.  Instead, I am still angry, and can't tell enough people of my shitty experience.  Being cheap is a bad business practice, and saves nothing in the end except a bad taste in one's psyche!!!!
author: Dolores S.

description: came here way too early in the morning one day. coffee wasn't that good.  i got the ham and cheese omelette and that thing was huge.. however, its not a place i would go to again.
author: JUDY L.

description: Family owned, long time San Francisco staple.
author: Matt G.

description: SERVICE IS TERRIBLE.  Staffed by high school girls who apparently dont have to be pleasant or know anything about the food service industry.  Food is comparable to Denny's or Lyons.  Low end diner food.  But the view is amazing, so the food can be terrible and it doesnt matter.  ONLY GO FOR THE VIEW, NOT THE FOOD.
author: Melanie J.

description: It is a greasy spoon, so do not have high expectations of a gourmet dining experience.  We eat here every time when we are in SF,for breakfast and lunch.  The sandwiches are filling and the fries very good.  The view alone is worth the meal ticket.  Views of the Sutro bath ruins and the ocean thru big expanse of windows.  Business is brisk, but worth the wait.  Bus stop right outside, will take you down to the beach and eventually the Zoo.  The burgers are good, and breakfast hearty, just right for a Midwest girl like me!  I am glad the decor has not changed in decades--why does it have to?!  It is part of the charm of the place.
author: Noran W.

description: although the decor of this small shack looks like you just stepped into a trailer, the price is way cheaper than the bitch (sutro's) across the street. a pretty decent brunch and you don't have to pay for the view.
author: Connie L.

description: I totally agree with C.L.'s review. It's a well-known place that's been there for a long time, but I would only go to enjoy the view on a clear day. The menu is small, and the food is average and overpriced.
author: Tami H.

description: The food at Louis' is very straight forward - omelettes, burger and fries etc.  That being said, the strawberry shake was delicious, the quality of the burger was excellent, and the apple pie with ice cream I got also great.  The prices are a little high, but the view is magnificent.  For a great burger and shake and a wonderful SF memory, I would recommend Louis'.
author: M R.
